Ok so why am I stuck in the reality where I am not president?
Seriously though, how does the universe (do we decide?) decide which reality we are experiencing? I'm not experiencing life in a branching sort of way, like in a choose your own adventure book. I am experiencing life in a continuous stream of consciousness. There's no real hint about when and where a branching is happening.

snippet.textDisplay:
The problem with Many Worlds is that it leads to absurdities like quantum immortality and Boltzmann brains.

If there are an infinite number of possibilities, then there are an infinite number of universes where when you die, you spontaneously appear in another universe as a thermal fluctuation, memories completely intact. Not only that, there would be an infinite number of universes where you spontaneously appear, memories intact, immediately die (presumably because you're in space or inside a star or whatever), then spontaneously appear again and die again, ad infinitum. That sounds a bit like the definition of hell to me, though conversely, there are also an infinite number of universes where you spontaneously appear in what we'd call paradise, live out your life, then die and do it again...

But even worse than the logical absurdities it leads to, Many Worlds can't be tested, which makes it more a tenet of faith than a scientific theory. If you can't prove via experiment (math is just math after all) that these other worlds exist, then it's not scientific, and you could just as easily make the claim that gods or devils or angels or demons collapse the wave function with equal validity to Many Worlds.
snippet.textOriginal:
The problem with Many Worlds is that it leads to absurdities like quantum immortality and Boltzmann brains.

If there are an infinite number of possibilities, then there are an infinite number of universes where when you die, you spontaneously appear in another universe as a thermal fluctuation, memories completely intact. Not only that, there would be an infinite number of universes where you spontaneously appear, memories intact, immediately die (presumably because you're in space or inside a star or whatever), then spontaneously appear again and die again, ad infinitum. That sounds a bit like the definition of hell to me, though conversely, there are also an infinite number of universes where you spontaneously appear in what we'd call paradise, live out your life, then die and do it again... 

But even worse than the logical absurdities it leads to, Many Worlds can't be tested, which makes it more a tenet of faith than a scientific theory.  If you can't prove via experiment (math is just math after all) that these other worlds exist, then it's not scientific, and you could just as easily make the claim that gods or devils or angels or demons collapse the wave function with equal validity to Many Worlds.

snippet.textDisplay:
if not infinite energy, many-worlds interpretation would require infinite information (with exponential growth) to account for all the branches... this puts the idea of a god on stress indeed :o)
If energy is conserved as said in the global wave function, then in each universe the equivalent Hubble constant would have to halve at each branching to keep the balance. This is not in line with experimental evidence.
Moreover I think many world interpretation is somehow unnatural, as it puts little relevance on causality and eventually on choices... What is the meaning of free will if all the choices are taken in at least one branch?
There are better interpretation of quantum mechanics phenomena... Bohm for example got "the unbroken wholeness of the entire universe" :)
snippet.textOriginal:

Moreover I think many world interpretation is somehow unnatural, as it puts little relevance on causality and eventually on choices... What is the meaning of free will if all the choices are taken in at least one branch?

snippet.textDisplay: You said that the results of Schrodinger's cat experiment exist in their own complete realities and those realities will never interact. However, the result of the double slit experiment (the wave pattern) is the result of two different realities of a single electron going through two slits. Doesn't that mean that different realities have some kind of interaction and there is a reality that could only exist because there is a reality where the cat is alive and a reality where the cat is dead?
snippet.textOriginal: You said that the results of Schrodinger's cat experiment exist in their own complete realities and those realities will never interact. Doesn't that mean that different realities have some kind of interaction and there is a reality that could only exist because there is a reality where the cat is alive and a reality where the cat is dead?

snippet.textDisplay:
This video explains the whole concept beautifully with gorgeous graphics and makes a compelling argument.

However 11:50 "The formalism [for Many Worlds] is so much cleaner and more elegant." Aesthetics are a very personal thing but I find an ever exploding multiplicity of worlds a little excessive. And we now have the proposal of a near infinite number of universes each with different values for various physical constants. It seems like Physics was lean and mean when I was born and has been getting steadily more obese since. :-)

The other issue with Many Worlds is that it doesn't make any falsifiable predictions different from other interpretations as far as I know and so doesn't really count as a scientific theory (unlike Quantum Mechanics as a whole of course).
snippet.textOriginal:
This video explains the whole concept beautifully with gorgeous graphics and makes a compelling argument.

However 11:50 "The formalism [for Many Worlds] is so much cleaner and more elegant."  Aesthetics are a very personal thing but I find an ever exploding multiplicity of worlds a little excessive. And we now have the proposal of a near infinite number of universes each with different values for various physical constants. It seems like Physics was lean and mean when I was born and has been getting steadily more obese since. :-)   

The other issue with Many Worlds is that it doesn't make any falsifiable predictions different from other interpretations as far as I know and so doesn't really count as a scientific theory (unlike Quantum Mechanics as a whole of course).

snippet.textDisplay:
I have got a last question:
In a experience that can cause two different reactions, A and B, with each reaction having 50% chance to occur, there are two branchs created, am I right?

And, in a experience that can lead to two different reactions, C and D, but this time with C having 90% chance to happen and D having only 10% chance to happen.

Are they 9 branchs were C happened and 1 where it is D which occured? Or are they 50 A-branchs, 50 B-branchs, 90 C-branchs and 10 D-branchs? But why 100 in total ? Why not 1000 or 10000000? Is there a limit or a way to measure this ?

snippet.textDisplay:
The fact that the mathematics "works" is irrelevant to the philosophy. I think that Schroedinger made the fundamental mistake of believing that superposition and probability were in effect functions of the same part of reality. That the universe is constantly splitting I agree is an elegant thought, and is also one way of expressing an aspect of my theory that the universe is, essentially and always, binary; that is, that at any single moment there are only two choices for anything, on or off, black or white, to do or to refrain from doing, to happen or not to happen. These drift off exponentially into countless zillions of choices - or possibilities, or quantum states, every instant of time.
Edit to add: But the idea that it is only observation that defines reality is flawed, and is simple to prove false UNLESS we all experience a completely different reality, and I see where the multiverse theory comes from, but can't accept it.
snippet.textOriginal:
The fact that the mathematics "works" is irrelevant to the philosophy.  I think that Schroedinger made the fundamental mistake of believing that superposition and probability were in effect functions of the same part of reality. That the universe is constantly splitting I agree is an elegant thought, and is also one way of expressing an aspect of my theory that the universe is, essentially and always, binary; that is, that at any single moment there are only two choices for anything, on or off, black or white, to do or to refrain from doing, to happen or not to happen. These drift off exponentially into countless zillions of choices - or possibilities, or quantum states, every instant of time.
Edit to add: But the idea that it is only observation that defines reality is flawed, and is simple to prove false UNLESS we all experience a completely different reality, and I see where the multiverse theory comes from, but can't accept it.

snippet.textDisplay:
I still cannot get past the feeling that a lot of this is drastically wrong and waiting to be reconstructed by some genius that recreates quantum mechanics or creates a whole new field that works better. I am under no illusion that explaining the universe should for some reason make sense and be intuitive to humans. But the many worlds and the "lets just accept the math because thats what it says" attitude doesnt make any sense to me. The "rate may be infinite" line just gets breezed over, but my understanding is that every spin of ever roulette wheel around the globe gets an individual split where every number was hit. Or even more, every collision of particles in the atmosphere gets a world where they rebound in a different direction. Every step you take gets a new world where every possibility happens to you with each step including having a heart attack. All just branching independently in each moment.


It doesnt make any sense to me

snippet.textDisplay:
We should probably consider the possibility that when particles pop out of existence, they go into a parallel universe, and this is why we see odd behavior at such tiny scales. If particles also popped into from other parallel universes like they were entangled, from a parallel universe that branches off from ours and has the same laws of physics. If particles are entering our universe at the same rate that they're disappearing and the same particles are appearing and disappearing, then likely, the multiverse is comprised of all the different states of all particles in our universe, just at different times.

If this doesn't make sense, I can explain further. Just imagine you could see the near infinite number of particles around you, that each one, was, say, the size of a grain of sand. In reality, they're much tinier. They could still make macroscopic objects look solid (or liquid), even with billions of particles fluctuating in and out of existence.

That's how I see the multiverse. Imagine autumn leaves falling. In our universe, they fall at exactly where we observe them. In a parallel universe, they are arranged in a different pattern. All patterns are realized, no matter how absurd, which means that entropy is in balance, which technically doesn't break the laws of physics. But, entropy is still likely increasing, if at each quantum state, a new universe is created. Perhaps the atoms make copies of themselves and new universes form when there is more matter and energy than there should be.

Also, what if the cat survived the poison somehow by some other random state? Haha, Erwin...I got you.
snippet.textOriginal:
We should probably consider the possibility that when particles pop out of existence, they go into a parallel universe, and this is why we see odd behavior at such tiny scales. If particles also popped into from other parallel universes like they were entangled, from a parallel universe that branches off from ours and has the same laws of physics. If particles are entering our universe at the same rate that they're disappearing and the same particles are appearing and disappearing, then likely, the multiverse is comprised of all the different states of all particles in our universe, just at different times. 

If this doesn't make sense, I can explain further. Just imagine you could see the near infinite number of particles around you, that each one, was, say, the size of a grain of sand. In reality, they're much tinier. They could still make macroscopic objects look solid (or liquid), even with billions of particles fluctuating in and out of existence.

That's how I see the multiverse. Imagine autumn leaves falling. In our universe, they fall at exactly where we observe them. In a parallel universe, they are arranged in a different pattern. All patterns are realized, no matter how absurd, which means that entropy is in balance, which technically doesn't break the laws of physics. But, entropy is still likely increasing, if at each quantum state, a new universe is created. Perhaps the atoms make copies of themselves and new universes form when there is more matter and energy than there should be.

Also, what if the cat survived the poison somehow by some other random state? Haha, Erwin...I got you.

snippet.textDisplay: Parallel worlds don't exist. It's a fanciful theory posited by atheist scientists who don't want to accept that the universe (and everything in it) had a beginning in the finite past; a scientifically proven fact, btw. Because to accept a beginning to the universe is to acknowledge that someone outside of our universe necessarily caused it to exist. Not a something, but rather a someone. More specifically, an immaterial, spaceless, timeless, immensely powerful, personal someone who chose to bring the universe into existence at some point in the finite past.
snippet.textOriginal: Parallel worlds don't exist. Because to accept a beginning to the universe is to acknowledge that someone outside of our universe necessarily caused it to exist. Not a something, but rather a someone. More specifically, an immaterial, spaceless, timeless, immensely powerful, personal someone who chose to bring the universe into existence at some point in the finite past.

snippet.textDisplay:
16:50 I call it the "incorrect indifference principle". The usual "indifference principle" says that if there's no reason to think one of several outcomes is more likely, then their probabilities are equal.
In this fallacy, people think that because "Yes" and "No" are both possible, they are equally possible, which is an incorrect use of indifference principle.
snippet.textOriginal:
16:50 I call it the "incorrect indifference principle". The usual "indifference principle" says that if there's no reason to think one of several outcomes is more likely, then their probabilities are equal.
In this fallacy, people think that because "Yes" and "No" are both possible, they are equally possible, which is an incorrect use of indifference principle.

snippet.textDisplay:
TL;DR: As I was writing this, it occurred to me that perhaps what people mean by "X happens in some world" is "X is an event in the probability space of many-worlds". Is that it? It feels like a tautological definition of 'happening' - "if it can happen, it does" - but it does appear to agree with Professor Carroll's description of all worlds simultaneously contributing a small weight to the total wave function. It's just not what I intuitively understand by the statement "X happens", which is something more empirical like "X is among the set of samples drawn from this distribution".


---


I've never been sure what to think of the "somewhere, an alternative version of you is president" interpretation. Not every possible event necessarily happens, even if you get infinitely many shots at it - for example, each real number in [0,1] has a chance of being hit by a dart thrown at that interval, but if you throw a countably-infinite number of darts, almost all numbers in [0,1] will remain un-hit. In this example, the individual events have probability 0. I initially thought the second Borel-Cantelli lemma guaranteed that an event with probability >0 must eventually happen, given infinitely-many attempts, but you would need to view the event as the union of separate events "X happens at time t_a", "X happens at time t_b" for a, b, ... in some index set, and somehow have all those events be independent, for BC2 to apply. For the above example: "the dart hits 0.827 at time 1, at time 2, ..." isn't sufficient to guarantee 0.827 is eventually hit using BC2, but eventually hitting any interval [0.827 - epsilon, 0.827 + epsilon] is guaranteed, if throws are independent. Without independence, I'm not aware (meaning I imagine I'm ignorant!) of any result that guarantees a particular realisation of a distribution must eventually occur, given enough samples.


To come back to the specific example: I would have thought the event "a version of me is president" doesn't necessarily have probability >0 of being true at any one time if it hinges on particular sets of particle interactions, each having probability 0 and not necessarily being dense enough to have a combined probability >0. Insert the TL;DR here ;) It isn't at all clear to me that any specific (and not truly impossible) event must happen under the latter - and I would say more standard - definition of 'happening'. I'm very happy that this video has (possibly) helped me to understand what physicists mean when they make this claim, but I still wonder whether I'm missing something and actually they do use the latter definition. In either case, from a purely probabilistic perspective, I'm keen to know: is it possible to guarantee that one of a specific sequence of events - even with each having probability 0 - occurs, if the number of opportunities is taken to have a sufficiently large infinite cardinality? [Some sort of generalisation of Borel-Cantelli, I suppose.]
snippet.textOriginal:
TL;DR: As I was writing this, it occurred to me that perhaps what people mean by "X happens in some world" is "X is an event in the probability space of many-worlds". Is that it? It feels like a tautological definition of 'happening' - "if it can happen, it does" - but it does appear to agree with Professor Carroll's description of all worlds simultaneously contributing a small weight to the total wave function. It's just not what I intuitively understand by the statement "X happens", which is something more empirical like "X is among the set of samples drawn from this distribution".


---


I've never been sure what to think of the "somewhere, an alternative version of you is president" interpretation. Not every possible event necessarily happens, even if you get infinitely many shots at it - for example, each real number in [0,1] has a chance of being hit by a dart thrown at that interval, but if you throw a countably-infinite number of darts, almost all numbers in [0,1] will remain un-hit. In this example, the individual events have probability 0. I initially thought the second Borel-Cantelli lemma guaranteed that an event with probability >0 must eventually happen, given infinitely-many attempts, but you would need to view the event as the union of separate events "X happens at time t_a", "X happens at time t_b" for a, b, ... in some index set, and somehow have all those events be independent, for BC2 to apply. For the above example: "the dart hits 0.827 at time 1, at time 2, ..." isn't sufficient to guarantee 0.827 is eventually hit using BC2, but eventually hitting any interval [0.827 - epsilon, 0.827 + epsilon] is guaranteed, if throws are independent. Without independence, I'm not aware (meaning I imagine I'm ignorant!) of any result that guarantees a particular realisation of a distribution must eventually occur, given enough samples.


To come back to the specific example: I would have thought the event "a version of me is president" doesn't necessarily have probability >0 of being true at any one time if it hinges on particular sets of particle interactions, each having probability 0 and not necessarily being dense enough to have a combined probability >0. Insert the TL;DR here ;) It isn't at all clear to me that any specific (and not truly impossible) event must happen under the latter - and I would say more standard - definition of 'happening'. I'm very happy that this video has (possibly) helped me to understand what physicists mean when they make this claim, but I still wonder whether I'm missing something and actually they do use the latter definition. In either case, from a purely probabilistic perspective, I'm keen to know: is it possible to guarantee that one of a specific sequence of events - even with each having probability 0 - occurs, if the number of opportunities is taken to have a sufficiently large infinite cardinality? snippet.textDisplay:
3:29 Here it is assumed that consciousness can be reduced to the interaction of photons and electrons - and thus is able to be in a quantum state. And then we can conclude that many realities exist at the same time.

But if consciousness is something non-physical that is able to collapse the wave-functions of the physical world then we would only have one world.


So in the end it seems like it comes down to a discussion of whether naturalism/materialism is true or not. Or what do you say?
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Then the question I ask here is ==> If let's say a certain particle is not about to be observed, hence they're in the state of superposition. But the outcome must be determined so how does that particle suddenly knows where it needs to be in order to be observed/entangled for then it to have a certain outcome?

Now what I mean is let's say if we are playing a game, the programmer needs to program for a certain outcome. But the problem with it lies when we start doing that. Now whenever I've seen someone program open world games. If we do a certain task (let's take an example of a game like GTA5) if our player does a certain task (let's say he steals a vehicle), the vehicle may or may not have been there depending upon the situation of that player being there or not there, and depending upon that it must be determined what's going on within the entire game for it to have a specific outcome (what do I mean by that is if we're put on a certain task most of our outcome related path/projection has already been determined. The AI within the game simply needs to determine what we need in order to reach a possible outcome) If the AI within the game is going on a certain way it should completely change it's state depending upon our determination of the mission we're willing to execute. So in turn it puts those vehicles on the path, But here lies the broader problem. The AI does not always know which vehicle we're going to choose in that certain mission at that certain point of time, and what path we're going to take in order for us to reach to maybe a destination from where we need to proceed the game further (let's say there are 8 paths). So it plays the stimulation unless and until we choose our ride and then the stimulation proceeds.Then it needs to determine depending upon us which path we're going to choose to take. and needs to prepare in advanced for anything we're going to do within the game.

BUT the thing here is that the AI needs to prepare for every possible situational outcome depending upon our situation. It needs to play/prepare every sequence of actions depending upon our choice of the path we're going to take. And when we choose to take it, only then is it that the game can proceed further. But there's another problem that needs to be solved here... (as the AI doesn't know when we're going to take over a vehicle, and when it is we are going to determine to proceed to a certain outcome). But in any case it most likely has ran through most of the basic situations we might be in. (In quantum world that means we've most likely been through all the situations prior to experiencing that, based on the nature of the reality we're in and the way it is programmed)

So depending upon the situation there's not just 1 or 2 possible states. There are infinite number of states we can be in. with infinite number of possible outcome. With infinite number of different situations. And with an infinite variation within the time.

Now coming back to my question... That particle most likely needs a guide in order for it to act a certain way in order for us to proceed with our reality. What is that thing that's guiding it. Who is determining the position of that particle and how it comes to interact with us? What is that thing,
that's binding us to that particle? Because it certainly seems like we're already living the reality we've been through but not in reality... (Midfuck right? But precisely defines "Déjà vu")

There's more to this. But I don't have the time to write more... 😂😂

whether we believe the cat is alive or dead is MEANINGLESS to the cat....and assumptions can prove NOTHING. Since quantum theory - as all mathematical theories depends on the ASSUMPTION that every set of 3 contains 3 units, and since we have not OBSERVED every set of 3 to verify and PROVE that all sets of 3 contain 3 units - quantum theory, indeed ALL theories remain UNPROVEN until we have inspected EVERY set of 3 and have the PROOF we need that number theory is TRUTH.... till then, they shall remain theories, not FACTS ... unfortunately for the administrators of academia, when theories are treated as FACT - the conclusions are invariably FALSEHOOD.
Space does not expand bend stretch or warp - it's already there, wherever we'd like to expand bend stretch or warp it to ... it's EVERYWHERE we've looked....and if we could bend space back onto it's self, we'd end up with space^2 - another MEANINGLESS falsehood.
Is cotton, wool, nylon or kevlar the "fabric" of space?
The apples grown on my tree last year which are 99.99999999% space between and within their atoms, SHOULD have grown to the size of SUN according to academia's best cooperative prediction of the current rate of expansion of the spacial metric ... THEY DID NOT!!!!!!!!

snippet.textDisplay: I think the many worlds theory is a gimmick. Just because we cannot make exact predictions about a system does not mean it therefore can't be deterministic. It's also very convenient that the fundamental premise cannot be physically tested. Yes, QM is difficult to understand and entanglement & observer effect are crazy to think about but so was everything else we now understand to people 100's of years ago. This theory feels sub-optimal at best, but its cool to see people take an interest. Maybe somebody watching this will grow up to become a physicist who finally figures it out.
snippet.textOriginal: I think the many worlds theory is a gimmick. Just because we cannot make exact predictions about a system does not mean it therefore can't be deterministic. It's also very convenient that the fundamental premise cannot be physically tested. Yes, QM is difficult to understand and entanglement & observer effect are crazy to think about but so was everything else we now understand to people 100's of years ago. This theory feels sub-optimal at best, but its cool to see people take an interest. Maybe somebody watching this will grow up to become a physicist who finally figures it out.

snippet.textDisplay:
What the wave function branching tells you, is just that elementary particles and atoms get shuffled in every possible way.
Sociological, behavioral, and macroscopic phenomena in general cannot be reduced to the behavior of atoms and particles though.

So basically, even if some of your electrons branch out to have different spins, that doesn't mean that there's a scenario in which you become president of the USA or get a Nobel or whatever.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: Many worlds interpretation is the reason why I hold more reservation towards 'traditional', Back-to-the-Future style time travel to the future than I do towards time travel to the past in general despite numerous paradoxes associated with it. At some point the machine gotta ask which version of 2015 or 2020 or 2100 that you want to visit.

snippet.textDisplay: Wouldn't this require, at some level, an infinite amount of energy to create a 'new universe'.  If energy is conserved, then eventually at some point, there would not be enough energy to create a new quantum event?  If its conserved, then its a closed box and the total 'universal' energy is limited.

snippet.textDisplay:
1. Assuming infinite universal possibility splits.
2. Unlimited versions of YOU out there(a you who's Prez, a you whos a pro tennis player, etc.)
3. Wouldn't there also be even more divergent variations of you? (A you that LOOKS different, has slightly different DNA, etc etc.)
4. And if that's the case. Would that mean that everyone is also just a different variation of you?

snippet.textDisplay:
From a philosophical perspective, many worlds is just shifting the issue. Instead of the question "why does the quantum state decay one way or the other?" the question becomes "why do I perceive reality in one way or the other?" or even "why is my conciousness in one way or the other?"
So it might be a nice tool for simulation, but our reality, the way we collectively perceive it, is only a single state. So why are we in this specific incarnation of the many worlds?
snippet.textOriginal:

So it might be a nice tool for simulation, but our reality, the way we collectively perceive it, is only a single state. So why are we in this specific incarnation of the many worlds?

snippet.textDisplay: I thought even if the universe was infinite big (as in 3 dimensions) it doesn't mean infinite mass/matter. In other words, there might not be an edge to the universe but the likelihood to find another identical version of yourself is slim because of limited amount of mass/galaxies.
snippet.textOriginal: I thought even if the universe was infinite big (as in 3 dimensions) it doesn't mean infinite mass/matter. In other words, there might not be an edge to the universe but the likelihood to find another identical version of yourself is slim because of limited amount of mass/galaxies.

snippet.textDisplay: I think the video could benefit from a pro-Copenhagen perspective, surely the many-worlds interpretation isn't universally supported among experts? I find it difficult to understand why the many-worlds interpretation is preferable to Copenhagen besides the fact that it seems to fit better with our own preconceived notions of the universe being deterministic, and leaves some unanswered questions (Why is my consciousness transferred to one copy over the other, for one). It'd be interesting to see a discussion on it to help clarify the strengths and weaknesses of the two (and other) interpretations, if we're going to be presenting arguments for one over the other.
snippet.textOriginal: I think the video could benefit from a pro-Copenhagen perspective, surely the many-worlds interpretation isn't universally supported among experts? I find it difficult to understand why the many-worlds interpretation is preferable to Copenhagen besides the fact that it seems to fit better with our own preconceived notions of the universe being deterministic, and leaves some unanswered questions (Why is my consciousness transferred to one copy over the other, for one). It'd be interesting to see a discussion on it to help clarify the strengths and weaknesses of the two (and other) interpretations, if we're going to be presenting arguments for one over the other.

snippet.textDisplay: There is something I don't understand. In slit experiment "worlds" affect each other (electron goes through both slits and affects the other possibility) but in Schrodinger's cat only one result happens (cat either lives or dies, kind of like electron going only through one slit and not creating the pattern). Why are these experiments used as if they represent the same thing? What am I missing?
snippet.textOriginal: There is something I don't understand. In slit experiment "worlds" affect each other (electron goes through both slits and affects the other possibility) but in Schrodinger's cat only one result happens (cat either lives or dies, kind of like electron going only through one slit and not creating the pattern). I'VE GOT THE ANSWER!

THEORY SOLVED. (Drop Mic)
